channel.title: NYT > World > Americas
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 The New York Times Company

item.title: How a Sabotaged Ankle Monitor Ended Bolsonaro’s House Arrest
item.description: Shortly before he was expected to start serving a 27-year sentence, Brazil’s former president took a soldering iron to his tracking device.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ionova
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Federal District’s Secretariat for Penitentiary Administration
item.media:description: The damaged ankle monitor of former President Jair Bolsonaro of Brazil, in a still image taken from a video released by the Federal District’s Secretariat for Penitentiary Administration.

item.title: Haitians Rejoice Over Their First World Cup Berth in 50 Years
item.description: The national team’s success in landing a World Cup slot gave Haitians around the world a momentary reprieve from their country’s deep crises.
item.dc:creator: James Wagner
item.media:description: Fans in Port-au-Prince, the capital, celebrated Haiti’s defeat of Nicaragua on Tuesday to qualify for the 2026 FIFA World Cup.

item.title: Texas Men Plotted Coup of Haitian Island to Enslave Women and Children, U.S. Says
item.description: The men, who planned to recruit homeless people for the invasion, took Haitian Creole classes and one enrolled in the U.S. Air Force to prepare for an attack by sailboat, prosecutors said.
item.dc:creator: Rylee Kirk
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: The island of Gonave as seen from Port-au-Prince, Haiti. Two Texas men were indicted in a murder and kidnapping plot that called for staging a coup of the island, federal prosecutors said.

item.title: Jair Bolsonaro Arrested in Brazil Amid Fears He Might Flee to Avoid Prison
item.description: The arrest came days before the former president was expected to be ordered to begin a 27-year prison sentence for staging a failed coup.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ionova
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Jair Bolsonaro during his house arrest in Brasília on Friday. The former president was arrested the next morning.

item.title: Cannon and Other Artifacts Are Recovered From San José Shipwreck
item.description: Colombian scientists also retrieved three coins and a porcelain cup from the San José, which treasure hunters have come to call the Holy Grail of shipwrecks.
item.dc:creator: Rylee Kirk
item.media:description: A photograph released by the Colombian government shows President Gustavo Petro examining a cannon that was recovered from the wreckage of the San José, a Spanish galleon that sank in 1708.

item.title: Are Fighter Jets Canada’s ‘Bargaining Chip’ in Trade Talks?
item.description: Canada began a review of its fighter jet deal with the United States after President Trump imposed tariffs. Now, Sweden is back with a sales pitch for its own jets.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Spencer Colby/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mark Carney and King Carl XVI Gustaf of Sweden at a state dinner in Ottawa this week. Sweden wants to sell fighter jets manufactured by Saab, a Swedish company, to Canada.

item.title: A Socialist Priest Embraces Venezuela’s Maduro, an Autocratic Leader
item.description: The Rev. Numa Molina, a Jesuit priest, has championed the poor for decades. Now, he is a power broker and a confidant of Venezuela’s embattled president, Nicolás Maduro.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev and Adriana Loureiro Fernandez
item.media:description: People line up to take photos with Father Numa Molina after a Mass in Marizapa, Venezuela.

item.title: 3 Children Are Injured in Grizzly Bear Attack in British Columbia
item.description: The children were among 11 people who were hurt when a grizzly attacked a school group in a remote part of British Columbia, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: Aimee Ortiz and Hannah Ziegler
item.media:credit: Jonathan Hayward/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Grizzly bears in Tweedsmuir Provincial Park near Bella Coola, British Columbia.

item.title: Satellite Data Reveals How the U.S. Navy Is Deployed Near Venezuela
item.description: The Times identified nearly 100 locations traversed by naval vessels across a two-and-a-half-month period to determine what the military pressure campaign against Venezuela looks like at sea.
item.dc:creator: Riley Mellen
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: The guided-missile destroyer Gravely leaving a port in Trinidad and Tobago in late October. It is among several U.S. Navy vessels sailing near the coast of Venezuela.

item.title: Fátima Bosch of Mexico Wins 2025 Miss Universe Pageant Marred by Scandal
item.description: Fátima Bosch was crowned in Thailand on Friday. The competition got off to a rocky start this month when she briefly walked out after being scolded by an organizer.
item.dc:creator: Francesca Regalado
item.media:description: Mexico's Fátima Bosch was named Miss Universe on Friday.

item.title: Survivors Describe Deadly Snowstorm in Chilean Patagonia
item.description: Five tourists, from Mexico, Britain and Germany, died Monday on a popular hiking trail in the Torres del Paine National Park.
item.dc:creator: Livia Albeck-Ripka and Pascale Bonnefoy
item.category: Torres del Paine National Park (Patagonia, Chile)
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse, via Carabineros de Chile
item.media:description: A picture released by Chile’s Carabineros shows a rescue team at the end of their search and recovery operation for a group of tourists.

item.title: Hundreds of Invasive Goldfish to Be Culled From Ottawa Pond
item.description: Thousands washed ashore dead in the spring, but the fish are back. “They’re pretty hard to kill,” a biology professor said.
item.dc:creator: Rylee Kirk

item.title: U.S. Ambassador to Canada Channels Harsh Trump Tone
item.description: Pete Hoekstra’s bluntness is seen as undiplomatic by Canadian officials and interpreted as a way for the Trump administration to turn up the heat as trade talks drag on.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:credit: Jeff Mcintosh/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Pete Hoekstra, the American ambassador to Canada, speaking in Banff, Alberta, in September.

item.title: U.S. Ran a War Game on Ousting Maduro. Venezuela Fell Into Chaos.
item.description: An official U.S. government exercise during President Trump’s first term forecast turmoil and potential violence in a post-Maduro Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of a group loyal to President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela, during a rally in Caracas in September.

item.title: F.B.I. Hunt Intensifies for Ryan Wedding, Snowboarder Accused of Being a Drug Kingpin
item.description: Ryan Wedding, a former Olympic athlete said to be a major cocaine trafficker, is accused of ordering the murder of a witness who was set to testify against him.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:description: Ryan Wedding during the Salt Lake City Winter Olympics in 2002.

item.title: Police Found $1 Million Stashed in a Tub Under a Garage. The Government Gets to Keep It.
item.description: A court ruled that the hidden cash, which the police found while searching for an illegal gun in Ontario, did not lawfully belong to the man living on the property.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.media:description: Some of the money recovered from Marcel Breton’s home in Thunder Bay, Ontario, in 2009. The police were searching for an illegal handgun when they found large amounts of cash hidden around the property.

item.title: Mexico Is Now the United States’ Top Buyer
item.description: For first time in at least 30 years, the United States has exported more to Mexico than Canada, U.S. government data show, in a sign of how much North American trade has consolidated.
item.dc:creator: James Wagner
item.media:credit: Gabriel V. Cárdenas for The New York Times
item.media:description: Trucks moving goods from the United States to Mexico in February. “Mexico is the United States’ main trading partner,” said Marcelo Ebrard, Mexico’s economy minister.

item.title: Teenager Under Investigation After Stepsister Is Found Dead on Cruise Ship
item.description: Anna Kepner, 18, was found dead on the Carnival Horizon on Nov. 8. Her stepbrother, 16, is under an investigation related to her death, his mother wrote this week in a legal filing.
item.dc:creator: Claire Fahy
item.media:description: On Nov. 8, a young woman died on the Carnival Horizon cruise ship, above, while on a Caribbean voyage. Her stepbrother is under investigation for her death, according to a legal filing.

item.title: Alberta Invokes Last-Resort Constitutional Clause to Shield Trans Laws From Challenges
item.description: The western province’s conservative government has invoked a rarely used clause in Canada’s Constitution to shield its bills limiting transgender rights from legal challenges.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Amber Bracken for The New York Times
item.media:description: Danielle Smith, Alberta’s conservative premier, has framed the enactment of the bills as a matter of children’s safety.

item.title: Venezuela Doesn’t Produce Fentanyl. Trump Is Targeting It Anyway.
item.description: Lawmakers and narcotics experts say that the Trump administration’s efforts to tie Venezuela to the U.S. fentanyl crisis are misleading.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Customs and Border Protection chemist inspecting suspected fentanyl pills that were seized at a border crossing in San Diego.

item.title: For Victims of Sexual Assault on Cruise Ships, Justice Can Be Elusive
item.description: As cruise travel hits record demand, cases of sexual assault have also risen. Many accusers learn that the rights they had on land don’t always apply.
item.dc:creator: Ceylan Yeğinsu
item.media:description: Though the 2010 Cruise Vessel Security and Safety Act established training standards, only one crew member on each vessel must be trained in crime prevention and evidence gathering.

item.title: Trump Said to Authorize C.I.A. Plans for Covert Action in Venezuela
item.description: The president has signed off on possible operations inside Venezuela but has also reopened back-channel communications with the government of President Nicolás Maduro.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Pager, Julian E. Barnes and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: The next phase of the Trump administration’s escalating pressure campaign on the government of President Nicolás Maduro could be sabotage or some sort of cyber, psychological or information operations.

item.title: Ecuador Votes ‘No’ to Hosting U.S. Military Base
item.description: A vote on Sunday rejected the expansion of a foreign military presence. It came as the U.S. military’s campaign in waters near Latin America has been roiling the region.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky and José María León Cabrera
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Celebrations after the results of a constitutional referendum in Guayaquil, Ecuador, on Sunday.

item.title: Trump Team Calls Maduro a ‘Cartel’ Boss. That Word Doesn’t Mean What You Think.
item.description: Venezuelans coined a figure of speech for the phenomenon of generals corrupted by drug money: “Cartel de los Soles.” Then the United States started talking about it as a literal organization.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Trump Treasury Department officially labeled Cartel de los Soles a global terrorist entity in July.

item.title: U.S. Military Threat Puts Spotlight on Venezuela’s Allies
item.description: American adversaries are unlikely to help President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela fend off a concerted attack. But they have made toppling him harder.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: A Russian fighter jet and rocket launchers on display in San Carlos del Meta, Venezuela.

item.title: House Democrats Press for Vote to Bar Military Action in Venezuela
item.description: The effort would invoke the War Powers Act, which expedites action on measures limiting the president’s war-making authority. It faces long odds in the G.O.P.-led House.
item.dc:creator: Robert Jimison
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Gregory Meeks of New York, the top Democrat on the Foreign Affairs Committee, is leading the effort in the House.

item.title: Trump Gives Mixed Messages About Military Action Against Venezuela
item.description: President Trump said that he was open to talking with President Nicolás Maduro but that the United States has “to take care of Venezuela” as the U.S. builds a military force in the Caribbean.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Pager
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Allison Robbert for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump in the Oval Office on Monday. Last month, Mr. Trump called off efforts to reach a diplomatic agreement with Venezuela, but the president has raised the possibility of renewed engagement.

item.title: Worker Error Is Faulted After Israeli-Born Canadian Hits Passport Snag
item.description: A student in Montreal, who was born in Kfar Saba, Israel, said she was initially told she could not list Israel as her birth country on her passport.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson

item.title: 2 Charged in Over 300 Thefts at Mausoleums in Toronto Area
item.description: The thefts took place during the daytime when the pair would enter mausoleums to swipe necklaces and other jewelry from remains, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: Johnny Diaz

item.title: High Beef Prices? Trump Official Blames Biden and Migrants.
item.description: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said migrants were bringing sick cows across the border, snarling beef supply chains.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:description: For President Trump, who served fast food sandwiches to the Clemson University football team during its 2019 visit to the White House, few meals hit closer to home than hamburgers.

item.title: We Can Now Track Individual Monarch Butterflies. It’s a Revelation.
item.description: Scientists used tiny new sensors to follow the insects on journeys that take thousands of miles to their winter colonies in Mexico.
item.dc:creator: Dan Fagin and Jonathan Corum
item.media:credit: Hannah Beier for The New York Times

item.title: The ‘Donroe Doctrine’: Trump’s Bid to Control the Western Hemisphere
item.description: President Trump has tightened the U.S. grip on the Americas by rewarding allies and punishing rivals. That has upended the region’s politics.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump aboard Air Force One on Friday. His administration has shown its interest in stronger control of Latin America, which promises major benefits.

item.title: Hydropower Is Getting Less Reliable as the World Needs More Energy
item.description: Demand for power is growing fast, but hydro plants, the oldest source of clean energy, are struggling because of droughts, floods and other extreme weather linked to climate change.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Penn and Ruth Fremson
